elements.content: Seven new silver ethynediide complexes containing ancillary heteroaromatic N-donor ligands, namely, Ag2C2·4AgCF3CO2­·(bipyH)­(CF3CO2)­·H2O (1), Ag2C2­·7AgCF3CO2­·(H3O)­(CF3CO2)­·2(bipyH2)­(CF3CO2)2­·3H2O (2), 2Ag2C2­·8AgCF3CO2·6L1 (L1 = pyrazole) (3), Ag2C2­·4AgCF3CO2­·2L2 (L2 = 3,5-dimethylpyrazole) (4), Ag2C2­·4AgCF3CO2­·2L3 (L3 = 1,2,4-triazole) (5), Ag2C2­·10AgCF3CO2­·2L4 (L4 = 4,5-dihydro-3-(4-pyridinyl)-2H-benz(g)-indazole) (6), and Ag2C2­·5AgCF3CO2­·2(H3O)­(CF3CO2)­·3(AgL5 2)­(CF3CO2)­·2(L5H)­(CF3CO2)­·2(H2O) (L5 = benzimidazole) (7) have been synthesized under hydrothermal conditions and characterized by single crystal X-ray analysis. Directed by N-donor ligands of different bulkiness and disposition of coordinating sites, various silver chain-type architectures (compounds 1 and 3–6) and discrete molecular structures (2 and 7) were assembled. In the case of 1 and 2, the influence of nonincorporated additive agents (NH4)2HPO4 and H2C2O4·H2O on product formation was also investigated.

Directed by N-donor ligands of different bulkiness and disposition of coordinating sites, various silver chain-type architectures (compounds 1 and 3-6) and discrete molecular structures (2 and 7) were assembled. In the case of 1 and 2, the influence of nonincorporated additive agents (NH4)2HPO4 and H2C2O4⋅H2O on product formation was also investigated.

elements.content: With selected heteroaromatic N-donor ligands as structure-directing agents, seven new silver ethynediide complexes built of C2@Ag n cages have been synthesized under hydrothermal conditions and characterized by X-ray crystallography

elements.content: Over the past dozen years, we and other research groups have focused on the rational design of supramolecular architectures of different dimensions based on multinuclear silver(I) aggregates containing alkynyl ligands. In our systematic investigation of the structural chemistry of Ag2C2 (silver ethynediide or silver acetylenediide), we have achieved some success in controlling structure diversity by introducing ancillary ligands to direct the assembly process. Ag2C2 is an explosive powder that is insoluble in all common solvents, but it can be dissolved in a concentrated aqueous solution of one or more soluble silver(I) salts via the formation of labile polyhedral C2@Ag n species each composed of n Ag+ vertices and an encapsulated C2 2– dianion. Such C2@Ag n species can be utilized as structure building units in the rational design of discrete molecular and higher-dimensional coordination architectures with various ancillary ligands, which include polyoxometalate, betaine, crown ether, phosphonate, and N-donor ligands.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Over the past dozen years, we and other research groups have focused on the rational design of supramolecular architectures of different dimensions based on multinuclear silver(I) aggregates containing alkynyl ligands. In our systematic investigation of the structural chemistry of Ag2C2 (silver ethynediide or silver acetylenediide), we have achieved some success in controlling structure diversity by introducing ancillary ligands to direct the assembly process. Ag2C2 is an explosive powder that is insoluble in all common solvents, but it can be dissolved in a concentrated aqueous solution of one or more soluble silver(I) salts via the formation of labile polyhedral C2@Ag n  species each composed of n Ag+ vertices and an encapsulated C2 2- dianion. Such C2@Ag n  species can be utilized as structure building units in the rational design of discrete molecular and higher-dimensional coordination architectures with various ancillary ligands, which include polyoxometalate, betaine, crown ether, phosphonate, and N-donor ligands.

elements.content: To further understand the influence of different reaction conditions and ancillary ligands, we decided to introduce heteroaromatic N-donor ligands of different steric bulk into the silver-ethynediide reaction system with trifluoroacetate as inductive agent and counteranion. The selected N-donor ligands can be classified as follows: rigid linear ligand (4,4′-bipyridine, written as bipy for short), small-size ligands (pyrazole, 3,5-dimethylpyrazole, 1,2,4-triazole), and bulkier ligands (4,5-dihydro-3-(4-pyridinyl)-2H-benz(g)-indazole and benzimidazole) (Chart ).

elements.content: All chemicals obtained from commercial sources were of analytically pure grade and used without further purification: silver nitrate (RFCL, 99.9%), silver trifluoroacetate (Acros, 98%), silver tetrafluoroborate (Aldrich, 98%), 4,4′-bipyridine (Aldrich, 98%), pyrazole (Acros, 98%), 3,5-dimethylpyrazole (Aldrich, 99%), 1,2,4-triazole (Aldrich, 98%), 4,5-dihydro-3-(4-pyridinyl)-2H-benz(g)-indazole (Aldrich, 99%), and benzimidazole (Aldrich, 98%). IR spectra were recorded at room temperature on a Nicolet Impact 420 FTIR spectrometer as KBr pellets in the range of 4000–400 cm–1 with a resolution of 2 cm–1. Elemental analysis (C, H, N) was performed by the Analysis and Testing Center of Shanghai Institute of Organic Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences. Ag2C2 was prepared as described previously.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Reagents and Instrumentation

All chemicals obtained from commercial sources were of analytically pure grade and used without further purification: silver nitrate (RFCL, 99.9%), silver trifluoroacetate (Acros, 98%), silver tetrafluoroborate (Aldrich, 98%), 4,4'-bipyridine (Aldrich, 98%), pyrazole (Acros, 98%), 3,5-dimethylpyrazole (Aldrich, 99%), 1,2,4-triazole (Aldrich, 98%), 4,5-dihydro-3-(4-pyridinyl)-2H-benz(g)-indazole (Aldrich, 99%), and benzimidazole (Aldrich, 98%). IR spectra were recorded at room temperature on a Nicolet Impact 420 FTIR spectrometer as KBr pellets in the range of 4000-400 cm-1 with a resolution of 2 cm-1. Elemental analysis (C, H, N) was performed by the Analysis and Testing Center of Shanghai Institute of Organic Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences. Ag2C2 was prepared as described previously.

elements.content:
CAUTION! Ag2C2 is highly explosive in the dry state and should be stored in the wet form at −10 °C in the dark, and only a small quantity is to be used for subsequent synthesis.

Ag<sub>2</sub>C<sub>2</sub>·4AgCF<sub>3</sub>CO<sub>2</sub>­·(bipyH)­(CF<sub>3</sub>CO<sub>2</sub>)­·H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>1</bold>)

Moist Ag2C2 (≈100 mg) was added to a concentrated aqueous solution (1 mL) of AgCF3CO2 (0.44 g, 2 mmol) and AgBF4 (0.380 g, 2 mmol) in a beaker, and the mixture was stirred until the solution was saturated. The excess Ag2C2 was filtered off, and then 4,4′-bipyridine (25 mg) and (NH4)2HPO4 (53 mg) were added to the filtrate. The resulted suspension was placed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel reaction vessel and subjected to hydrothermal conditions at 110 °C for 30 h and subsequently cooled to room temperature at 5 °C/h. Colorless prism-like crystals of 1 were isolated in 75% yield. Compound 8 decomposes above 260 °C; IR: ν = 2065 cm–1 (w, νCC); elemental analysis: calcd (%) for C22H11Ag6F15N2O11 (M r = 1411.55): C 18.72, H 0.79, N 1.99. found: C 18.42, H 0.98, N 2.15.

elements.content: Crystal data were collected on a Bruker Smart Apex II CCD diffractometer with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 293(2) K. The intensities were corrected for Lorentz and polarization factors, as well as for absorption by the multiscan method. The structures were solved by the direct method and refined by full-matrix least-squares fitting on F 2 by SHELX-97, and all non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters. For complex 1, silver atom Ag6 is disordered over two positions, and the site-occupancy ratio of Ag6/Ag6′ is 0.66:0.34. For complex 2, fluorine atoms F13, F14, F15 from a trifluoroacetate group are disordered over two positions and refined with an assigned site-occupancy ratio of 0.5:0.5; the 4,4′-bipyridine ligands are fully protonated in accordance with the requirement of charge balance. In 3, oxygen atom O4 is disordered over two positions and refined with an assigned site-occupancy ratio of 0.5:0.5. The crystallographic data and structure refinement parameters for 1–7 are listed in . Important bond distances are listed in .
elements.clean_text:
Single-Crystal Structure Determination

Crystal data were collected on a Bruker Smart Apex II CCD diffractometer with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 293(2) K. The intensities were corrected for Lorentz and polarization factors, as well as for absorption by the multiscan method. The structures were solved by the direct method and refined by full-matrix least-squares fitting on F 2 by SHELX-97, and all non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters. For complex 1, silver atom Ag6 is disordered over two positions, and the site-occupancy ratio of Ag6/Ag6' is 0.66:0.34. For complex 2, fluorine atoms F13, F14, F15 from a trifluoroacetate group are disordered over two positions and refined with an assigned site-occupancy ratio of 0.5:0.5; the 4,4'-bipyridine ligands are fully protonated in accordance with the requirement of charge balance. In 3, oxygen atom O4 is disordered over two positions and refined with an assigned site-occupancy ratio of 0.5:0.5. The crystallographic data and structure refinement parameters for 1-7 are listed in . Important bond distances are listed in .

elements.content: Complexes 1–7 were synthesized under hydrothermal conditions from the reaction of Ag2C2 dissolved in a concentrated solution of AgCF3CO2/AgBF4 with various ancillary N-donor ligands. The reagents and synthesis procedures of 1 and 2 are mostly identical, except that different additive agents were employed. The present series of complexes feature three different types of silver cages: C2@Ag6 (5), C2@Ag8 (1, 3, 4, and 6), and C2@Ag9 (2 and 7).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Complexes 1-7 were synthesized under hydrothermal conditions from the reaction of Ag2C2 dissolved in a concentrated solution of AgCF3CO2/AgBF4 with various ancillary N-donor ligands. The reagents and synthesis procedures of 1 and 2 are mostly identical, except that different additive agents were employed. The present series of complexes feature three different types of silver cages: C2@Ag6 (5), C2@Ag8 (1, 3, 4, and 6), and C2@Ag9 (2 and 7).

elements.content: Complex 1 has a branched-tree architecture, which is composed of two kinds of C2@Ag8 silver cages each lying on a crystallographic 2-axis (Figure a, labeled A and B). Silver cage A contains the ethynediide C1C1a, which has π interactions with atom Ag3/Ag3a and σ interactions with seven silver atoms at Ag–C bond distances lying in the range of 2.129(9)–2.651(9) Ǻ. In a similar manner, C2C2a species is encapsulated in cage B, being consolidated by eight σ-type bonds with Ag–C bond lengths lying in the range of 2.134(9)–2.477(8) Ǻ. As illustrated in Figure b, the silver cages are arranged alternately in an ABAB···fashion and fused together to yield a C 2-symmetric silver column along the b direction via edge sharing (Ag6–Ag6a) and Ag···Ag interactions (Ag1–Ag4). This silver column is further stabilized by the trifluoroacetate ligands and the bipyridine ligand with its nitrogen atom N1 coordinated to Ag4 at 2.164(1) Ǻ (Figure c). The bipyridine ligand is protonated at the other terminal to satisfy the charge balance and serve as a branch of the tree-like architecture. The adjacent silver columns are interconnected by N–H···O and O–H···F hydrogen bonds to yield a three-dimensional supramolecular network, of which the solvated water molecules serve as both acceptors and donors involving the monoprotonated bipyridine and the trifluoroacetate ligands (Figure d).
elements.clean_text:
Description of Crystal Structures

Ag2C2⋅4AgCF3CO2⋅(bipyH)(CF3CO2)⋅H2O (1)

Complex 1 has a branched-tree architecture, which is composed of two kinds of C2@Ag8 silver cages each lying on a crystallographic 2-axis (Figure a, labeled A and B). Silver cage A contains the ethynediide C1C1a, which has π interactions with atom Ag3/Ag3a and σ interactions with seven silver atoms at Ag-C bond distances lying in the range of 2.129(9)-2.651(9) Ǻ. In a similar manner, C2C2a species is encapsulated in cage B, being consolidated by eight σ-type bonds with Ag-C bond lengths lying in the range of 2.134(9)-2.477(8) Ǻ. As illustrated in Figure b, the silver cages are arranged alternately in an ABAB⋅⋅⋅fashion and fused together to yield a C 2-symmetric silver column along the b direction via edge sharing (Ag6-Ag6a) and Ag⋅⋅⋅Ag interactions (Ag1-Ag4). This silver column is further stabilized by the trifluoroacetate ligands and the bipyridine ligand with its nitrogen atom N1 coordinated to Ag4 at 2.164(1) Ǻ (Figure c). The bipyridine ligand is protonated at the other terminal to satisfy the charge balance and serve as a branch of the tree-like architecture. The adjacent silver columns are interconnected by N-H⋅⋅⋅O and O-H⋅⋅⋅F hydrogen bonds to yield a three-dimensional supramolecular network, of which the solvated water molecules serve as both acceptors and donors involving the monoprotonated bipyridine and the trifluoroacetate ligands (Figure d).

elements.content: (a) The basic structural unit of 1 comprising two kinds of centrosymmetric C2@Ag8 cages labeled A and B. Selected bond lengths and distances [Å]: C1C1a 1.18(2), C2C2a 1.21(2), Ag···Ag 2.760(7)–3.372(2). (b) A portion of the C 2-symmetric silver(I) column generated from edge sharing of silver cages and argentophilic interactions. elements.content: In the crystal structure of 2, the building block is a Ag9 cage with an enclosed ethynediide dianion stabilized by multiple σ- and π-type interactions with its vertices in the range of 2.188(6)–2.461(6) Å (Figure a). The C2@Ag9 cage is in the shape of a slightly distorted monocapped square antiprism, in which the atom sets Ag1–Ag2–Ag3–Ag4 and Ag5–Ag6–Ag7–Ag8 are each coplanar with mean deviation of 0.185 and 0.056 Å, respectively, from the corresponding least-squares plane, and they make a dihedral angle of 6.34°. The silver cage is stabilized by 12 independent trifluoroacetate ligands (Figure b). Of the four independent water molecules, O1W takes the form of a (H3O)+ cation to satisfy the charge balance and serves as an aqua ligand to bind Ag5 at 2.431(1) Å. The two independent bipy molecules are each fully protonated and form donor hydrogen bonds to two water molecules. The resulting H2O···HbpeH···H2O moiety serves as a bridge, and adjacent silver cages are cross-linked by N–H···O, O–H···O, and C–H···O hydrogen bonds to give a three-dimensional supramolecular architecture (Figure c).

elements.content: In compound 3, the independent ethynediide dianions are accommodated in irregular Ag8 cages labeled A and B (Figure a). The C1C2 species in cage A is stabilized by five σ and two π bonding interactions with Ag–C bond lengths in the range of 2.073(2)–2.587(2) Ǻ. Similarly, C3C4 in silver cage B is stabilized by five σ and two π bonding interactions with Ag–C bond lengths in the range of 2.066(2)–2.672(2) Ǻ. These two kinds of silver cages are fused into an ABAB··· infinite chain running along the a direction via edge-sharing of type Ag1–Ag2 and Ag4–Ag7, with additional argentophilic linkage (Ag6–Ag9) (Figure b). The silver chains are further consolidated by the trifluoroacetate ligands via μ2-O,O′ and μ3-O,O′,O′ coordination modes, and six independent imidazole ligands are attached to Ag3, Ag8, Ag9, Ag10, Ag11, Ag12, respectively (Figure c). Adjacent silver chains are cross-linked by C–H···F hydrogen bonding involving trifluoroacetate ligands and pyrazole ligands, and thus a three-dimensional supramolecular architecture is formed (Figure d).

elements.content: In the crystal structure of compound 4, the basic building unit is a centrosymmetric C2@Ag8 silver cage in the shape of a distorted square antiprism (Figure a). The two atom sets Ag1–Ag2–Ag3a–Ag2c and Ag1a–Ag2b–Ag2a–Ag3 are each coplanar with mean deviation of 0.084 and 0.084 Å from the corresponding least-squares plane, respectively, making a dihedral angle of 7.09°. The encapsulated C1C1a moiety is bound to the vertices of the silver cage via the μ8-η1,η1,η1,η1,η2,η2,η2,η2 coordination mode with Ag–C bond lengths in the range of 2.097(1)–2.616(1) Å. The C2@Ag8 cages are repeated along the c direction to generate an infinite chain by sharing the cage edges (Ag2–Ag2) and argentophilic interactions (Ag1–Ag3) (Figure b). Such chain is further consolidated by trifluoroacetate ligands via μ2-O,O and μ3-O,O′,O′ coordination modes, with the 3,5-dimethypyrazole ligands attached to it at Ag1 (Figure c). The adjacent silver chains are cross-linked by C–H···F hydrogen bonding involving 3,5-dimethylpyrazole and trifluoroacetate to yield a three-dimensional supramolecular architecture (Figure d).

elements.content: The crystal structure of 5 contains a single cage C2@Ag6 in the shape of an irregular pentagonal pyramid (Figure a). The encapsulated C2 2– species interact with the vertices of the silver cage by two π and four σ bonds in the range of 2.155(5)–2.555(5) Å. The cages are fused together via argentophilic interaction of the type Ag3–Ag1d to generate an infinite chain along the c direction (Figure b). The silver chain is further consolidated by trifluoroacetate ligands, and the L3 ligand bridge adjacent silver cages by coordination to silver atoms of type Ag1 and Ag2b (Figure c). Of the L3 ligand, its remaining third nitrogen atom is involving in donor hydrogen bonding with a trifluoroacetate ligand to bridge adjacent silver chains, and thus a three-dimensional supramolecular architecture is formed (Figure d).

elements.content: Similar to that in 4, the structure building block in 6 is also a C2@Ag8 cage (Figure a). The C1C2 species is enclosed in the partially opened Ag8 polyhedron and stabilized by mixed σ/π Ag–C interactions in the range of 2.100(9)–2.584(9) Å. The silver cages share the Ag2–Ag2a and Ag3–Ag3b edges to form a sinuous infinite chain in the a direction (Figure b). The argentophilic silver chain is further consolidated by the trifluoroacetate ligands via μ2-O,O and μ3-O,O′,O′ coordination modes. The branch-like L4 ligand is attached to the silver skeleton by coordination to Ag1 via its indazole ring (Figure c), and it also forms donor C–H···F and N–H···O hydrogen bonds with the trifluoroacetate F and O atoms, respectively, to yield a three-dimensional supramolecular architecture (Figure d).

elements.content: The building block of compound 7 is a C2@Ag9 single cage with a crystallographic 2-axis passing through the C1, C2 atoms and the centers of the Ag3–Ag3a and Ag4–Ag4a edges (Figure a). The site occupancy of Ag4 is 1/2, so that Ag4 and Ag4a can be regarded as a single silver atom disordered over two positions. The trifluoroacetate ligands function in the μ2-O,O and μ3-O,O′,O′ coordination modes, surrounding the silver cage to form a discrete molecular unit. As shown in Figure b, beside the silver cage, the asymmetric unit of 7 also contains two external silver atoms, four independent independent L5 ligands, and two independent water molecules. Of the four independent L5 ligands, three of them are unprotonated (of type N1–N2, N3–N4, N5–N6) and coordinate to external silver atoms to form AgL5 2 moieties, and the remaining L5 ligand of type N7–N8 is 1-H protonated to form (L5H)+ moiety. Of the two independent water molecules, O1W serves as an aqua ligand coordinated to Ag4 at 2.468(2) Å, and O2W is a lattice water molecule. The (L5H)+ moieties and O2W existing between the adjacent discrete silver cages function as bridges; thus a supramolecular layer parallel to ab plane is formed with hydrogen bonding of type O6···O2W···N8c–C42c–N7c···O8c (Figure c). It is also noteworthy that the AgL5 2 moieties are accommodated between the host layers and attach to the silver skeletons via hydrogen bonds O12···N4d, O5···N2e and O3d···N6; thus, a three-dimensional supramolecular structure is formed (Figure c).

elements.content: By the use of different acids as additive agents (diammonium hydrogen phosphate (NH4)2HPO4 for 1, and oxalic acid H2C2O4·H2O for 2), compound 1 and compound 2 were similarly prepared under hydrothermal conditions. In our previous work, a complex [Ag13(C2)2(CF3CO2)9­(bipy)4(H2O)3] was synthesized under similar hydrothermal conditions without any additive agent. Through structure comparison of these three compounds, the structure-directing effect of the additive agents can be assessed. In the crystal structure of [Ag13(C2)2­(CF3CO2)2­(bipy)4(H2O)3], the bipy ligands act in the bidentate mode to serving as linear connectors, by which the silver cages and external silver atoms are cross-linked to form a three-dimensional coordination network. In Ag2C2­·4AgCF3CO2­·(bipyH)­(CF3CO2)·H2O (1), the bipy ligand is monoprotonated, with one terminal attached to the silver chain and the other forming a donor hydrogen bond to a lattice water molecule. In Ag2C2·7AgCF3CO2­·(H3O)­(CF3CO2)­·2(bipyH2)­(CF3CO2)2·3H2O, both independent bipy ligands are protonated at their N terminals and serve as counter cations. The fully protonated bipy and H3O+ molecules function as hydrogen-bonding linkers between the discrete silver cages. Therefore, in the Ag2C2/AgCF3CO2/bipy reaction system, without or with (NH4)2HPO4/H2C2O4·H2O as additive structure-directing agents, the bipyridine ligand takes nonprotonated, 1H-protonated and 2H-protonated forms, leading to a 3D coordination network (compound [Ag13(C2)2­(CF3CO2)9­(bipy)4(H2O)3]), infinite coordination chain (compound 1), and discrete molecular (compound 2) structures, respectively. Notably, we found that compound 2 could not be generated by adding (NH4)2C2O4 into the Ag2C2/AgCF3CO2/bipy reaction system in place of H2C2O4, demonstrating that the structure-directing effect arises from the proton rather than the counterion. A plausible explanation of this finding is that both (NH4)2HPO4 and H2C2O4·H2O function as proton sources of increasing effectiveness for bipyridine.
elements.clean_text:
Induction Effect of Additive Agent

By the use of different acids as additive agents (diammonium hydrogen phosphate (NH4)2HPO4 for 1, and oxalic acid H2C2O4⋅H2O for 2), compound 1 and compound 2 were similarly prepared under hydrothermal conditions. In our previous work, a complex [Ag13(C2)2(CF3CO2)9(bipy)4(H2O)3] was synthesized under similar hydrothermal conditions without any additive agent. Through structure comparison of these three compounds, the structure-directing effect of the additive agents can be assessed. In the crystal structure of [Ag13(C2)2(CF3CO2)2(bipy)4(H2O)3], the bipy ligands act in the bidentate mode to serving as linear connectors, by which the silver cages and external silver atoms are cross-linked to form a three-dimensional coordination network. In Ag2C2⋅4AgCF3CO2⋅(bipyH)(CF3CO2)⋅H2O (1), the bipy ligand is monoprotonated, with one terminal attached to the silver chain and the other forming a donor hydrogen bond to a lattice water molecule. In Ag2C2⋅7AgCF3CO2⋅(H3O)(CF3CO2)⋅2(bipyH2)(CF3CO2)2⋅3H2O, both independent bipy ligands are protonated at their N terminals and serve as counter cations. The fully protonated bipy and H3O+ molecules function as hydrogen-bonding linkers between the discrete silver cages. Therefore, in the Ag2C2/AgCF3CO2/bipy reaction system, without or with (NH4)2HPO4/H2C2O4⋅H2O as additive structure-directing agents, the bipyridine ligand takes nonprotonated, 1H-protonated and 2H-protonated forms, leading to a 3D coordination network (compound [Ag13(C2)2(CF3CO2)9(bipy)4(H2O)3]), infinite coordination chain (compound 1), and discrete molecular (compound 2) structures, respectively. Notably, we found that compound 2 could not be generated by adding (NH4)2C2O4 into the Ag2C2/AgCF3CO2/bipy reaction system in place of H2C2O4, demonstrating that the structure-directing effect arises from the proton rather than the counterion. A plausible explanation of this finding is that both (NH4)2HPO4 and H2C2O4⋅H2O function as proton sources of increasing effectiveness for bipyridine.

elements.content: In conclusion, directed by a series of selected heteroaromatic N-donor ligands, seven new silver ethynediide complexes exhibiting structural diversity of their C2@Ag n cages have been hydrothermally synthesized and characterized by X-ray crystallography. Compound 2 and 7 have discrete molecule structures, both comprising C2@Ag9 silver cages consolidated by trifluoroacetate ligands, and the N-donor ligands are uncoordinated with the silver skeleton. Compound 1 and 3–6 are built of coordination chains, in which the N-donor ligands are attached to the silver chains in a branch-like fashion. Induced by acidic additive agents, compounds 1 and 2 synthesized in similar reaction condition are found to adopt very different crystal structures. The coordination behaviors of the N-donor ligands with small steric bulk (L1, L2 and L3) are similar in the silver ethynediide/trifluoroacetate reaction system, further consolidating the respective C2@Ag n cages. Although the L4 ligand is of relatively larger size, its coordination behavior is similar to those of the three small-size ligands. In compound 7, the independent L5 ligands play different roles: three in the neutral form to give AgL5 2 moieties with external silver atoms, and the other as monocation L5H+ for supramolecular assembly.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In conclusion, directed by a series of selected heteroaromatic N-donor ligands, seven new silver ethynediide complexes exhibiting structural diversity of their C2@Ag n  cages have been hydrothermally synthesized and characterized by X-ray crystallography. Compound 2 and 7 have discrete molecule structures, both comprising C2@Ag9 silver cages consolidated by trifluoroacetate ligands, and the N-donor ligands are uncoordinated with the silver skeleton. Compound 1 and 3-6 are built of coordination chains, in which the N-donor ligands are attached to the silver chains in a branch-like fashion. Induced by acidic additive agents, compounds 1 and 2 synthesized in similar reaction condition are found to adopt very different crystal structures. The coordination behaviors of the N-donor ligands with small steric bulk (L1, L2 and L3) are similar in the silver ethynediide/trifluoroacetate reaction system, further consolidating the respective C2@Ag n  cages. Although the L4 ligand is of relatively larger size, its coordination behavior is similar to those of the three small-size ligands. In compound 7, the independent L5 ligands play different roles: three in the neutral form to give AgL5 2 moieties with external silver atoms, and the other as monocation L5H+ for supramolecular assembly.

elements.content: The CC bond lengths of compounds 1–6 occur in the range of 1.177(2)–1.220(9) Å, which are in accord with previous results reported for silver ethynediide complexes. The C2@Ag n cage is quite labile, and its nuclearity and geometry can be influenced by many factors, such as coexisting anions, ancillary ligands, and solvate molecules. In the present instance, the difference in nucleophilicity of the N-donor ligands plays a significant role in the variation of observed CC bond lengths.

The C2@Ag n  cage is quite labile, and its nuclearity and geometry can be influenced by many factors, such as coexisting anions, ancillary ligands, and solvate molecules. In the present instance, the difference in nucleophilicity of the N-donor ligands plays a significant role in the variation of observed CC bond lengths.

CAUTION! Ag2C2 is highly explosive in the dry state and should be stored in the wet form at −10 °C in the dark, and only a small quantity is to be used for subsequent synthesis.

Ag<sub>2</sub>C<sub>2</sub>·4AgCF<sub>3</sub>CO<sub>2</sub>­·(bipyH)­(CF<sub>3</sub>CO<sub>2</sub>)­·H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>1</bold>)

Moist Ag2C2 (≈100 mg) was added to a concentrated aqueous solution (1 mL) of AgCF3CO2 (0.44 g, 2 mmol) and AgBF4 (0.380 g, 2 mmol) in a beaker, and the mixture was stirred until the solution was saturated. The excess Ag2C2 was filtered off, and then 4,4′-bipyridine (25 mg) and (NH4)2HPO4 (53 mg) were added to the filtrate. The resulted suspension was placed in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel reaction vessel and subjected to hydrothermal conditions at 110 °C for 30 h and subsequently cooled to room temperature at 5 °C/h. Colorless prism-like crystals of 1 were isolated in 75% yield. Compound 8 decomposes above 260 °C; IR: ν = 2065 cm–1 (w, νCC); elemental analysis: calcd (%) for C22H11Ag6F15N2O11 (M r = 1411.55): C 18.72, H 0.79, N 1.99. found: C 18.42, H 0.98, N 2.15.

Ag<sub>2</sub>C<sub>2</sub>·7AgCF<sub>3</sub>CO<sub>2</sub>­·(H<sub>3</sub>O)­(CF<sub>3</sub>CO<sub>2</sub>)­·2(bipyH<sub>2</sub>)­(CF<sub>3</sub>CO<sub>2</sub>)<sub>2</sub>­·3H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>2</bold>)

Compound 2 was synthesized in a manner similar to compound 1 using H2C2O4·2H2O (60 mg) instead of (NH4)2HPO4 (53 mg). Colorless prism-like crystals of 2 were isolated in 71% yield.
